title: JavaScript Basics | Labuladong Algo Notes
content:
JavaScript Basics

labuladongOriginalAbout 1510 words

JavaScript Basics

labuladongOriginalAbout 1510 words
labuladong labuladong labuladong Original About 1510 words About 1510 words

Since my Algorithm Visualization Panel currently only supports JavaScript, this tutorial is aimed not only at JavaScript beginners but also at readers using other programming languages, helping everyone quickly get started with the algorithm visualization panel.

For Readers Using Other Languages, This is Optional Content

I have pre-written the visualization code for each problem and will even tell you in the article or comments how to operate the visualization panel to observe the algorithm execution process. So, even if you are not familiar with JavaScript, you can still benefit from the visualization panel accompanying each problem.

However, some readers may want to modify my preset code or visualize their own creative ideas, in which case a basic understanding of JavaScript syntax is necessary. This article is prepared for those readers.

With the advancement of AI tools, you generally don't need to write JS from scratch. You can use AI tools to translate code from other languages into JS. You only need to understand basic JS syntax to comprehend the code. So, as long as you are familiar with any other programming language, spending five minutes on the following content will enable you to use the visualization panel effectively.

Basic JavaScript Syntax

Variable Declaration

Let's start with variable declaration in JavaScript, which can be done in three ways: var, let, const.

const is used to declare constants that cannot be modified once set. This is generally used in engineering code, and in algorithm code, its use is optional.

const a = 1;
// error will be thrown
a = 2;

Both var and let can declare regular variables, but the visibility of the variables they declare is different. var is more of a legacy issue. In general, you can consider their effects to be the same in the visual panel.

let str = "hello world";
str = "world"
// output world
console.log(str);

if (true) {
    // the str here and the str outside are two different variables
    let str = "hello";
    // output hello
    console.log(str);
}

In my visualization code, the top-level functions are generally declared using var. This is because the function signatures provided on LeetCode for JavaScript are declared with var, so I have followed suit. However, if you want to change it to let, that's perfectly fine as well.

Function Declaration

JavaScript function declarations are quite straightforward, like this:

function add(a, b) {
    return a + b;
}
// output 3
console.log(add(1, 2));

The declaration of this function is the same as in other programming languages. However, in JavaScript, you might also see the following anonymous function declaration, which is essentially assigning an anonymous function to a variable. The usage is the same either way:

// replacing let with var will have the same effect
let add2 = function(a, b) {
    return a + b;
}
// output 3
console.log(add2(1, 2));

// declare using ES6 arrow function
let add3 = (a, b) => {
    return a + b;
}
// output 3
console.log(add3(1, 2));

Functions declared with the function keyword and arrow functions declared with () => {} have some key differences, mainly in the behavior of the this pointer within the function body. However, this feature is rarely used in algorithm problems, so you can consider these two methods as equivalent.

Loop Control

Loop control in JavaScript is similar to other programming languages, with common constructs being for and while.

Using array traversal as an example, let's discuss the most common method, index-based iteration:

// Traverse an array
let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
for (let i = 0; i < arr.length; i++) {
    console.log(arr[i]);
}
// Output: 1 2 3 4 5

Then, there's the for...of method, which can directly iterate over elements:

// Traverse an array
let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
for (let item of arr) {
    console.log(item);
}
// Output: 1 2 3 4 5

Iterating with for ... of

Note that JavaScript uses of to iterate over array elements; do not use in. The in keyword has other purposes, which are not typically needed in algorithm problems, so I won't elaborate.

I know some other languages use in to iterate over array elements, so this is a reminder not to confuse them.

The while loop is similar to other languages. Here's a simple example:

let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
let i = 0;
while (i < arr.length) {
    console.log(arr[i]);
    i++;
}
// Output: 1 2 3 4 5

Conditional Statements

The usage of if else in JavaScript is the same as in other programming languages. Here is a simple example:

let a = 1;
if (a === 1) {
    console.log("a equals 1");
} else {
    console.log("a does not equal 1");
}

The Difference Between === and ==

There is a small pitfall here: the difference between == and === in JavaScript. The == operator returns true if the values are equal, while === returns true only if both the values and the types are equal. Similarly, != returns true if the values are not equal, and !== returns true only if both the values and the types are not equal.

For example, both null and undefined represent empty values in JavaScript. null == undefined is true, but null === undefined is false.

This distinction is a historical issue in JavaScript. When solving algorithm problems, you usually do not need to focus on such details. In most cases, both forms can be used.

Basic Data Structures in JavaScript

Strings

Strings in JavaScript work the same as in other languages. Here is an example:

let str = "hello world";
// output 11
console.log(str.length);
// output h
console.log(str[0]);
// output true
console.log(str === "hello world");

// split the string
let arr = str.split(" ");
// output ["hello", "world"]
console.log(arr);

// get a substring, multiple methods are available
// output hello
console.log(str.substring(0, 5));
// output hello
console.log(str.slice(0, 5));
// output hello
console.log(str.substring(0, 5));

// concatenate strings
let str2 = "world";
// output hello world world
console.log(str + " " + str2);

Arrays

There are several ways to create an array:

let arr1 = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
let arr2 = new Array(1, 2, 3, 4, 5);

// create an array of length 5, each element is undefined
let arr3 = new Array(5);

// create an array of length 5, each element is 0
let arr4 = new Array(5).fill(0);

Common Operations on Arrays:

let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];

// get the length of the array
// output 5
console.log(arr.length);

// get an element of the array
// output 1
console.log(arr[0]);

// modify an element of the array
arr[0] = 100;

// copy all elements of the array to a new array
let arr2 = arr.slice();
// this is also a method to copy an array
let arr3 = [...arr];

// add an element to the end of the array
arr.push(6);

// remove the last element from the array
arr.pop();

// add an element 888 to the beginning of the array
// not commonly used, as algorithms generally avoid adding or
// removing elements from positions other than the end of the array
arr.unshift(888);

// remove the first element from the array
// not commonly used, as algorithms generally avoid adding or
// removing elements from positions other than the end of the array
arr.shift();

Alright, understanding the above basic operations is more than enough for you to use arrays in algorithm problems.

Hash Table

In simple terms, objects in JavaScript can be understood as hash tables because JavaScript objects consist of key-value pairs. However, with the introduction of the Map type in ES6, we can be more formal and use the Map type to create hash tables.

Basic operations of Map:

let map = new Map();

// Add key-value pairs
map.set("a", 1);
map.set("b", 2);
map.set("c", 3);

// Retrieve key-value pairs
// Output 1
console.log(map.get("a"));

// Delete key-value pair
map.delete("a");

// Check if a key exists
// Output false
console.log(map.has("a"));
// Output true
console.log(map.has("b"));

// Iterate over key-value pairs
for (let key of map.keys()) {
    console.log(key, map.get(key));
}
// Output b 2 and c 3

This should cover most of it. If you encounter a situation you can't handle, just refer to the documentation.

Hash Set

The Set type introduced in ES6 is a hash set, used to store unique elements. The basic operations are as follows:

let set = new Set();

// Add elements
set.add(1);
set.add(2);
set.add(3);

// Delete an element
set.delete(1);

// Check if an element exists
// Output false
console.log(set.has(1));
// Output true
console.log(set.has(2));

// Traverse elements
for (let item of set) {
    console.log(item);
}
// Output 2 and 3

Other Special Data Structures

In algorithm problems, you may also encounter special data structures such as linked lists, trees, binary heaps, etc. These data structures are not built-in to JavaScript. However, my algorithm visualization panel has implemented these special data structures. You can refer to my Introduction to the Algorithm Visualization Panel for specific usage.

Basic JavaScript Syntax

Basic JavaScript Syntax Basic JavaScript Syntax

Variable Declaration

Variable Declaration Variable Declaration

Let's start with variable declaration in JavaScript, which can be done in three ways: var, let, const.

var, let, const

const is used to declare constants that cannot be modified once set. This is generally used in engineering code, and in algorithm code, its use is optional.

const 
const a = 1;
// error will be thrown
a = 2;
const a = 1;
// error will be thrown
a = 2;
const a = 1; // error will be thrown a = 2; const a = 1; const a = 1 ; // error will be thrown // error will be thrown a = 2; a = 2 ;

Both var and let can declare regular variables, but the visibility of the variables they declare is different. var is more of a legacy issue. In general, you can consider their effects to be the same in the visual panel.

var let var 
let str = "hello world";
str = "world"
// output world
console.log(str);

if (true) {
    // the str here and the str outside are two different variables
    let str = "hello";
    // output hello
    console.log(str);
}
let str = "hello world";
str = "world"
// output world
console.log(str);

if (true) {
    // the str here and the str outside are two different variables
    let str = "hello";
    // output hello
    console.log(str);
}
let str = "hello world"; str = "world" // output world console.log(str); if (true) { // the str here and the str outside are two different variables let str = "hello"; // output hello console.log(str); } let str = "hello world"; let str = "hello world" ; str = "world" str = "world" // output world // output world console.log(str); console . log ( str ); if (true) { if ( true ) { // the str here and the str outside are two different variables // the str here and the str outside are two different variables let str = "hello"; let str = "hello" ; // output hello // output hello console.log(str); console . log ( str ); } }

In my visualization code, the top-level functions are generally declared using var. This is because the function signatures provided on LeetCode for JavaScript are declared with var, so I have followed suit. However, if you want to change it to let, that's perfectly fine as well.

var var let

Function Declaration

Function Declaration Function Declaration

JavaScript function declarations are quite straightforward, like this:

function add(a, b) {
    return a + b;
}
// output 3
console.log(add(1, 2));
function add(a, b) {
    return a + b;
}
// output 3
console.log(add(1, 2));
function add(a, b) { return a + b; } // output 3 console.log(add(1, 2)); function add(a, b) { function add ( a , b ) { return a + b; return a + b ; } } // output 3 // output 3 console.log(add(1, 2)); console . log ( add ( 1 , 2 ));

The declaration of this function is the same as in other programming languages. However, in JavaScript, you might also see the following anonymous function declaration, which is essentially assigning an anonymous function to a variable. The usage is the same either way:

// replacing let with var will have the same effect
let add2 = function(a, b) {
    return a + b;
}
// output 3
console.log(add2(1, 2));

// declare using ES6 arrow function
let add3 = (a, b) => {
    return a + b;
}
// output 3
console.log(add3(1, 2));
// replacing let with var will have the same effect
let add2 = function(a, b) {
    return a + b;
}
// output 3
console.log(add2(1, 2));

// declare using ES6 arrow function
let add3 = (a, b) => {
    return a + b;
}
// output 3
console.log(add3(1, 2));
// replacing let with var will have the same effect let add2 = function(a, b) { return a + b; } // output 3 console.log(add2(1, 2)); // declare using ES6 arrow function let add3 = (a, b) => { return a + b; } // output 3 console.log(add3(1, 2)); // replacing let with var will have the same effect // replacing let with var will have the same effect let add2 = function(a, b) { let add2 = function ( a , b ) { return a + b; return a + b ; } } // output 3 // output 3 console.log(add2(1, 2)); console . log ( add2 ( 1 , 2 )); // declare using ES6 arrow function // declare using ES6 arrow function let add3 = (a, b) => { let add3 = ( a , b ) => { return a + b; return a + b ; } } // output 3 // output 3 console.log(add3(1, 2)); console . log ( add3 ( 1 , 2 ));

Functions declared with the function keyword and arrow functions declared with () => {} have some key differences, mainly in the behavior of the this pointer within the function body. However, this feature is rarely used in algorithm problems, so you can consider these two methods as equivalent.

function () => {} this

Loop Control

Loop Control Loop Control

Loop control in JavaScript is similar to other programming languages, with common constructs being for and while.

for while

Using array traversal as an example, let's discuss the most common method, index-based iteration:

// Traverse an array
let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
for (let i = 0; i < arr.length; i++) {
    console.log(arr[i]);
}
// Output: 1 2 3 4 5
// Traverse an array
let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
for (let i = 0; i < arr.length; i++) {
    console.log(arr[i]);
}
// Output: 1 2 3 4 5
// Traverse an array let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]; for (let i = 0; i < arr.length; i++) { console.log(arr[i]); } // Output: 1 2 3 4 5 // Traverse an array // Traverse an array let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]; let arr = [ 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 ]; for (let i = 0; i < arr.length; i++) { for ( let i = 0 ; i < arr . length ; i ++) { console.log(arr[i]); console . log ( arr [ i ]); } } // Output: 1 2 3 4 5 // Output: 1 2 3 4 5

Then, there's the for...of method, which can directly iterate over elements:

for...of 
// Traverse an array
let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
for (let item of arr) {
    console.log(item);
}
// Output: 1 2 3 4 5
// Traverse an array
let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
for (let item of arr) {
    console.log(item);
}
// Output: 1 2 3 4 5
// Traverse an array let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]; for (let item of arr) { console.log(item); } // Output: 1 2 3 4 5 // Traverse an array // Traverse an array let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]; let arr = [ 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 ]; for (let item of arr) { for ( let item of arr ) { console.log(item); console . log ( item ); } } // Output: 1 2 3 4 5 // Output: 1 2 3 4 5

Iterating with for ... of

Note that JavaScript uses of to iterate over array elements; do not use in. The in keyword has other purposes, which are not typically needed in algorithm problems, so I won't elaborate.

I know some other languages use in to iterate over array elements, so this is a reminder not to confuse them.

Iterating with for ... of

for ... of

Note that JavaScript uses of to iterate over array elements; do not use in. The in keyword has other purposes, which are not typically needed in algorithm problems, so I won't elaborate.

of in in

I know some other languages use in to iterate over array elements, so this is a reminder not to confuse them.

in

The while loop is similar to other languages. Here's a simple example:

while 
let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
let i = 0;
while (i < arr.length) {
    console.log(arr[i]);
    i++;
}
// Output: 1 2 3 4 5
let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
let i = 0;
while (i < arr.length) {
    console.log(arr[i]);
    i++;
}
// Output: 1 2 3 4 5
let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]; let i = 0; while (i < arr.length) { console.log(arr[i]); i++; } // Output: 1 2 3 4 5 let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]; let arr = [ 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 ]; let i = 0; let i = 0 ; while (i < arr.length) { while ( i < arr . length ) { console.log(arr[i]); console . log ( arr [ i ]); i++; i ++; } } // Output: 1 2 3 4 5 // Output: 1 2 3 4 5

Conditional Statements

Conditional Statements Conditional Statements

The usage of if else in JavaScript is the same as in other programming languages. Here is a simple example:

if else 
let a = 1;
if (a === 1) {
    console.log("a equals 1");
} else {
    console.log("a does not equal 1");
}
let a = 1;
if (a === 1) {
    console.log("a equals 1");
} else {
    console.log("a does not equal 1");
}
let a = 1; if (a === 1) { console.log("a equals 1"); } else { console.log("a does not equal 1"); } let a = 1; let a = 1 ; if (a === 1) { if ( a === 1 ) { console.log("a equals 1"); console . log ( "a equals 1" ); } else { } else { console.log("a does not equal 1"); console . log ( "a does not equal 1" ); } }

The Difference Between === and ==

There is a small pitfall here: the difference between == and === in JavaScript. The == operator returns true if the values are equal, while === returns true only if both the values and the types are equal. Similarly, != returns true if the values are not equal, and !== returns true only if both the values and the types are not equal.

For example, both null and undefined represent empty values in JavaScript. null == undefined is true, but null === undefined is false.

This distinction is a historical issue in JavaScript. When solving algorithm problems, you usually do not need to focus on such details. In most cases, both forms can be used.

The Difference Between === and ==

=== ==

There is a small pitfall here: the difference between == and === in JavaScript. The == operator returns true if the values are equal, while === returns true only if both the values and the types are equal. Similarly, != returns true if the values are not equal, and !== returns true only if both the values and the types are not equal.

== === == true === true != true !== true

For example, both null and undefined represent empty values in JavaScript. null == undefined is true, but null === undefined is false.

null undefined null == undefined true null === undefined false

This distinction is a historical issue in JavaScript. When solving algorithm problems, you usually do not need to focus on such details. In most cases, both forms can be used.

Basic Data Structures in JavaScript

Basic Data Structures in JavaScript Basic Data Structures in JavaScript

Strings

Strings Strings

Strings in JavaScript work the same as in other languages. Here is an example:

let str = "hello world";
// output 11
console.log(str.length);
// output h
console.log(str[0]);
// output true
console.log(str === "hello world");

// split the string
let arr = str.split(" ");
// output ["hello", "world"]
console.log(arr);

// get a substring, multiple methods are available
// output hello
console.log(str.substring(0, 5));
// output hello
console.log(str.slice(0, 5));
// output hello
console.log(str.substring(0, 5));

// concatenate strings
let str2 = "world";
// output hello world world
console.log(str + " " + str2);
let str = "hello world";

console.log(str.length);
// output h
console.log(str[0]);
// output true
console.log(str === "hello world");

// output ["hello", "world"]
console.log(arr);

// get a substring, multiple methods are available
// output hello
console.log(str.substring(0, 5));
// output hello
console.log(str.slice(0, 5));
// output hello
console.log(str.substring(0, 5));

// concatenate strings
let str2 = "world";
// output hello world world
console.log(str + " " + str2);
let str = "hello world"; // output 11 console.log(str.length); // output h console.log(str[0]); // output true console.log(str === "hello world"); // split the string let arr = str.split(" "); // output ["hello", "world"] console.log(arr); // get a substring, multiple methods are available // output hello console.log(str.substring(0, 5)); // output hello console.log(str.slice(0, 5)); // output hello console.log(str.substring(0, 5)); // concatenate strings let str2 = "world"; // output hello world world console.log(str + " " + str2); let str = "hello world"; let str = "hello world" ; // output 11 // output 11 console.log(str.length); console . log ( str . length ); // output h // output h console.log(str[0]); console . log ( str [ 0 ]); // output true // output true console.log(str === "hello world"); console . log ( str === "hello world" ); // split the string // split the string let arr = str.split(" "); let arr = str . split ( " " ); // output ["hello", "world"] // output ["hello", "world"] console.log(arr); console . log ( arr ); // get a substring, multiple methods are available // get a substring, multiple methods are available // output hello // output hello console.log(str.substring(0, 5)); console . log ( str . substring ( 0 , 5 )); // output hello // output hello console.log(str.slice(0, 5)); console . log ( str . slice ( 0 , 5 )); // output hello // output hello console.log(str.substring(0, 5)); console . log ( str . substring ( 0 , 5 )); // concatenate strings // concatenate strings let str2 = "world"; let str2 = "world" ; // output hello world world // output hello world world console.log(str + " " + str2); console . log ( str + " " + str2 );

Arrays

Arrays Arrays

There are several ways to create an array:

let arr1 = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
let arr2 = new Array(1, 2, 3, 4, 5);

// create an array of length 5, each element is undefined
let arr3 = new Array(5);

// create an array of length 5, each element is 0
let arr4 = new Array(5).fill(0);
let arr1 = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
let arr2 = new Array(1, 2, 3, 4, 5);

// create an array of length 5, each element is undefined
let arr3 = new Array(5);

// create an array of length 5, each element is 0
let arr4 = new Array(5).fill(0);
let arr1 = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]; let arr2 = new Array(1, 2, 3, 4, 5); // create an array of length 5, each element is undefined let arr3 = new Array(5); // create an array of length 5, each element is 0 let arr4 = new Array(5).fill(0); let arr1 = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]; let arr1 = [ 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 ]; let arr2 = new Array(1, 2, 3, 4, 5); let arr2 = new Array ( 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 ); // create an array of length 5, each element is undefined // create an array of length 5, each element is undefined let arr3 = new Array(5); let arr3 = new Array ( 5 ); // create an array of length 5, each element is 0 // create an array of length 5, each element is 0 let arr4 = new Array(5).fill(0); let arr4 = new Array ( 5 ). fill ( 0 );

Common Operations on Arrays:

let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];

// get the length of the array
// output 5
console.log(arr.length);

// get an element of the array
// output 1
console.log(arr[0]);

// modify an element of the array
arr[0] = 100;

// copy all elements of the array to a new array
let arr2 = arr.slice();
// this is also a method to copy an array
let arr3 = [...arr];

// add an element to the end of the array
arr.push(6);

// remove the last element from the array
arr.pop();

// add an element 888 to the beginning of the array
// not commonly used, as algorithms generally avoid adding or
// removing elements from positions other than the end of the array
arr.unshift(888);

// remove the first element from the array
// not commonly used, as algorithms generally avoid adding or
// removing elements from positions other than the end of the array
arr.shift();
let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];

// get the length of the array
// output 5
console.log(arr.length);

// get an element of the array
// output 1
console.log(arr[0]);

// modify an element of the array
arr[0] = 100;

// copy all elements of the array to a new array

// this is also a method to copy an array
let arr3 = [...arr];

// add an element to the end of the array
arr.push(6);

// remove the last element from the array
arr.pop();

// add an element 888 to the beginning of the array
// not commonly used, as algorithms generally avoid adding or
// removing elements from positions other than the end of the array
arr.unshift(888);

// remove the first element from the array
// not commonly used, as algorithms generally avoid adding or
// removing elements from positions other than the end of the array
arr.shift();

// add an element 888 to the beginning of the array // not commonly used, as algorithms generally avoid adding or // removing elements from positions other than the end of the array arr.unshift(888); // remove the first element from the array // not commonly used, as algorithms generally avoid adding or // removing elements from positions other than the end of the array arr.shift(); let arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]; let arr = [ 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 ]; // get the length of the array // get the length of the array // output 5 // output 5 console.log(arr.length); console . log ( arr . length ); // get an element of the array // get an element of the array // output 1 // output 1 console.log(arr[0]); console . log ( arr [ 0 ]); // modify an element of the array // modify an element of the array arr[0] = 100; arr [ 0 ] = 100 ; // copy all elements of the array to a new array // copy all elements of the array to a new array let arr2 = arr.slice(); Alright, understanding the above basic operations is more than enough for you to use arrays in algorithm problems.

Hash Table

Hash Table Hash Table

In simple terms, objects in JavaScript can be understood as hash tables because JavaScript objects consist of key-value pairs. However, with the introduction of the Map type in ES6, we can be more formal and use the Map type to create hash tables.

Map Map

Basic operations of Map:

Map 
let map = new Map();

// Add key-value pairs
map.set("a", 1);
map.set("b", 2);
map.set("c", 3);

// Retrieve key-value pairs
// Output 1
console.log(map.get("a"));

// Delete key-value pair
map.delete("a");

// Check if a key exists
// Output false
console.log(map.has("a"));
// Output true
console.log(map.has("b"));

// Iterate over key-value pairs
for (let key of map.keys()) {
    console.log(key, map.get(key));
}
// Output b 2 and c 3
let map = new Map();

// Add key-value pairs
map.set("a", 1);
map.set("b", 2);
map.set("c", 3);

// Retrieve key-value pairs
// Output 1
console.log(map.get("a"));

// Delete key-value pair
map.delete("a");

// Check if a key exists
// Output false
console.log(map.has("a"));
// Output true
console.log(map.has("b"));

// Iterate over key-value pairs
for (let key of map.keys()) {
    console.log(key, map.get(key));
}
// Output b 2 and c 3
let map = new Map(); // Add key-value pairs map.set("a", 1); map.set("b", 2); map.set("c", 3); // Retrieve key-value pairs // Output 1 console.log(map.get("a")); // Delete key-value pair map.delete("a"); // Check if a key exists // Output false console.log(map.has("a")); // Output true console.log(map.has("b")); // Iterate over key-value pairs for (let key of map.keys()) { console.log(key, map.get(key)); } // Output b 2 and c 3 let map = new Map(); let map = new Map (); // Add key-value pairs // Add key-value pairs map.set("a", 1); map . set ( "a" , 1 ); map.set("b", 2); map . set ( "b" , 2 ); map.set("c", 3); map . set ( "c" , 3 ); // Retrieve key-value pairs // Retrieve key-value pairs // Output 1 // Output 1 console.log(map.get("a")); console . log ( map . get ( "a" )); // Delete key-value pair // Delete key-value pair map.delete("a"); map . delete ( "a" ); // Check if a key exists // Check if a key exists // Output false // Output false console.log(map.has("a")); console . log ( map . has ( "a" )); // Output true // Output true console.log(map.has("b")); console . log ( map . has ( "b" )); // Iterate over key-value pairs // Iterate over key-value pairs for (let key of map.keys()) { for ( let key of map . keys ()) { console.log(key, map.get(key)); console . log ( key , map . get ( key )); } } // Output b 2 and c 3 // Output b 2 and c 3

This should cover most of it. If you encounter a situation you can't handle, just refer to the documentation.

Hash Set

Hash Set Hash Set

The Set type introduced in ES6 is a hash set, used to store unique elements. The basic operations are as follows:

Set 
let set = new Set();

// Add elements
set.add(1);
set.add(2);
set.add(3);

// Delete an element
set.delete(1);

// Check if an element exists
// Output false
console.log(set.has(1));
// Output true
console.log(set.has(2));

// Traverse elements
for (let item of set) {
    console.log(item);
}
// Output 2 and 3
let set = new Set();

// Add elements
set.add(1);
set.add(2);
set.add(3);

// Delete an element
set.delete(1);

// Check if an element exists
// Output false
console.log(set.has(1));
// Output true
console.log(set.has(2));

// Traverse elements
for (let item of set) {
    console.log(item);
}
// Output 2 and 3
let set = new Set(); // Add elements set.add(1); set.add(2); set.add(3); // Delete an element set.delete(1); // Check if an element exists // Output false console.log(set.has(1)); // Output true console.log(set.has(2)); // Traverse elements for (let item of set) { console.log(item); } // Output 2 and 3 let set = new Set(); let set = new Set (); // Add elements // Add elements set.add(1); set . add ( 1 ); set.add(2); set . add ( 2 ); set.add(3); set . add ( 3 ); // Delete an element // Delete an element set.delete(1); set . delete ( 1 ); // Check if an element exists // Check if an element exists // Output false // Output false console.log(set.has(1)); console . log ( set . has ( 1 )); // Output true // Output true console.log(set.has(2)); console . log ( set . has ( 2 )); // Traverse elements // Traverse elements for (let item of set) { for ( let item of set ) { console.log(item); console . log ( item ); } } // Output 2 and 3 // Output 2 and 3

Other Special Data Structures

Other Special Data Structures Other Special Data Structures

In algorithm problems, you may also encounter special data structures such as linked lists, trees, binary heaps, etc. These data structures are not built-in to JavaScript. However, my algorithm visualization panel has implemented these special data structures. You can refer to my Introduction to the Algorithm Visualization Panel for specific usage.
